spans.content: Review
Global prevalence of digital addiction in general population: A systematic review and meta-analysis
Shi-Qiu Meng a,1, Jia-Lu Cheng a,1, Yang-Yang Li a,1, Xiao-Qin Yang a, Jun-Wei Zheng a, Xiang-Wen Chang a, Yu Shi b, Yun Chen b, Lin Lu a,c, Yan Sun a,\*, Yan-Ping Bao a,\*, Jie Shi a,b,d,e,\*
National Institute on Drug Dependence and Beijing Key Laboratory of Drug Dependence, Peking University, Beijing, China
b Peking University Shenzhen Hospital, Shenzhen, China

Peking University Sixth Hospital, Peking University Institute of Mental Health, NHC Key Laboratory of Mental Health (Peking University), National Clinical Research Center for Mental Disorders (Peking University Sixth Hospital), Beijing, China
d The State Key Laboratory of Natural and Biomimetic Drugs, Peking University, Beijing, China
e The Key Laboratory for Neuroscience of the Ministry of Education and Health, Peking University, Beijing, China
ARTICLEINFO
Keywords:
Digital addiction
Behavioral addiction
Internet addiction
Gaming addiction
Prevalence
Meta-analysis
ABSTRACT

The present meta-analytic review aimed to synthesize the global prevalence characteristics of digital addiction in the general population. We searched PubMed, Embase, Cochrane Library, and PsycINFO for studies reporting prevalence of various subtypes of digital addiction published before October 31, 2021. Studies were eligible if they were published in peer-reviewed journals, used a validated tool to assess digital addiction, and passed the qualify assessment. In total, 498 articles with 507 studies were included in systematic review, and the meta-analysis included 495 articles with 504 studies covering 2,123,762 individuals from 64 countries. Global pooled prevalence estimates were
(95% CI, 22.73-31.73) for smartphone addiction,
(95% CI, 12.42-23.89) for social media addiction,
(95% CI, 12.90-15.65) for Internet addiction,
(95% CI, 5.75-11.66) for cybersex addiction, and

(95% CI, 4.80-7.57) for game addiction. Higher prevalence of digital addiction was found in Eastern Mediterranean region and low/upper-middle income countries. Males had higher risk for Internet and game addiction. An increasing trend of digital addiction during the past two decades was found, which dramatically worsened during COVID-19 pandemic. This study provides the first and comprehensive estimation for the global prevalence of multiple subtypes of digital addiction, which varied between regions, economic levels, time periods of publication, genders, and assessment scales.
PROSPERO ID: CRD42020171117.
1. Introduction
The number of active digital users was 4.66 billion for Internet, 4.32 billion for mobile Internet, and 4.2 billion for social media by January 2021 (Statista, 2021), with an average online time of
6.7\mathrm{h}

daily. However, persistent or recurrent use of digital media, referring to digital devices (e.g., computers, smartphone) and related activities (e.g., games, social media), could lead to digital addiction (Christakis, 2019; WHO, 2014). Digital addiction is an umbrella term incorporating subtypes of the long-standing problem of Internet addiction, the highly-discussed issue of game addiction, and the emerging topic on social media addiction, or other digital media addiction (Christakis, 2019).

Notably, digital addiction does not necessarily involve Internet use, and thus it includes not only addiction to online activities, but also addiction to offline activities using digital devices, such as offline game addiction (Almourad, McAlaney, Skinner, Pleya, & Ali, 2020; Christakis, 2019). Previous evidence showed that digital addiction caused significant impairments in health, study, work, and other social functions, and marked distress in personal, family, and social well-being (Bell, Bishop, & Przybylski, 2015; Dahl & Bergmark, 2020; WHO, 2014). Concerns about increased risks for digital addiction during the COVID-19 pandemic have also been raised (Kiraly et al., 2020). To provide basis for formulating prevention and treatment measures, it is urgent for systematically estimating the prevalence characteristics and contributors for digital

CUNICAL PSYCHOLOGY REVIEW

addiction (Potenza, Higuchi, & Brand, 2018).
Epidemiological studies showed the prevalence of different subtypes of digital addiction ranging from
to

, with great variations in subtypes of digital media, diagnostic tools, and methodological quality, and bias from small sample size, single population, non-random sampling, and invalidated screening methods (Alhassan et al., 2018; Feng, Ramo, Chan, & Bourgeois, 2017). Previous systematic reviews had only summarized the prevalence of a single subtype of digital addiction (e.g., Internet addiction (Cheng & Li, 2014; Kuss, Griffiths, Karila, & Billieux, 2014; Pan, Chiu, & Lin, 2020; Su, Han, Jin, Yan, & Potenza, 2019; Weinstein & Lejoyeux, 2010), game addiction (Ferguson, Coulson, & Barnett, 2011; Mihara & Higuchi, 2017; Pan et al., 2020; Stevens, Dorystyn, Delfabbro, & King, 2020), or smartphone addiction (Sahu, Gandhi, & Sharma, 2019; Sohn, Rees, Wildridge, Kalk, & Carter, 2019)), and focused on specific populations in specific regions (e.g., Chinese college students (Li et al., 2018); Shao et al., 2018), American youths (Moreno, Jelenchick, Cox, Young, & Christakis, 2011), Southeast Asian (Chia et al., 2020), Iranian (Modara et al., 2017), people from Gulf countries (Al-Khani et al., 2021), healthcare professionals (Buneviciene & Bunevicius, 2020), medical students (Zhang, Lim, Lee, & Ho, 2018), and adolescents (Fam, 2018; Paulus, Ohmann, von Gontard, & Popow, 2018)). Until now, it still lacks a comprehensive estimate for the prevalence characteristics of different subtypes of digital addiction in the general population worldwide, which could provide critical information for addressing the global status of digital addiction and benefit the formulation of coping strategies, especially under the impact of COVID-19.

Thus, we conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis to make comprehensive estimate of the prevalence of 5 subtypes of digital addiction in the general population at a global level, and display the differences between sub-populations. We also aimed to investigate the effects of demographic, geographic, and clinical characteristics, as well as other associated factors on the prevalence of multiple subtypes of digital addiction.
2. Methods
2.1. Search strategy and selection criteria

This systematic review and meta-analysis was conducted according to the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analysis (PRISMA, Appendix A-B in the Supplement) (Moher, Liberati, Tetzlaff, & Altman, 2009). The protocol of the study was preregistered (https://www.crd.york.ac.uk/PROSPERO/, PROSPERO ID: CRD42020171117).

We searched PubMed, Embase, Cochrane Library, and PsycINFO to identify relevant literature on the prevalence of digital addiction in the general population published before October 31, 2021. We used search items related to digital devices or activities (internet OR digital OR screen OR cyber* OR net OR online OR media OR electronic device* OR electronic gadgets OR computer OR mobile OR phone OR smartphone OR television OR TV OR video OR facebook OR game OR gaming), problematic use (addict* OR use OR dependen* OR overuse OR abuse OR disorder OR excessive OR effects OR habits OR misuse OR pathological OR problem* OR compulsive OR heavy), and prevalence (prevalence OR survey OR rate OR scale OR screening OR situation OR epidemic OR epidemiological OR occurrence OR investigation). Full searching details for each database and subtypes of digital addiction included were listed (Appendix C in the Supplement).

The inclusion criteria were as follows: studies published on peer-reviewed journals; cross-sectional studies or longitudinal studies providing baseline data; investigations based on general population; definitions and measurement tools of general or subtypes of digital addiction were clearly reported; directly providing the prevalence rate or sufficient data to calculate the prevalence. No language restriction was applied. Additional records were identified through screening of

reference lists of identified studies and relevant reviews. We excluded studies based on selective sample, reviews, conference abstracts and theses. For multiple articles using data from the same population, the one with the largest sample size and the most comprehensive results was included. We contacted authors to request lacking or additional data. Four researchers independently screened on each included study. Discrepancies were adjudicated through discussion with the review team.
2.2. Data extraction and quality assessment

For each study, data were independently extracted using a standardized scale, and cross-checked by four researchers. The non-English records were translated. The prevalence estimates in this study were calculated by dividing the number of people screened as "addiction" by the number of valid respondents.

The quality of each study was assessed by a modified version of Newcastle-Ottawa Scale (NOS) (Stang, 2010) from five dimensions: sample representativeness, sample size, response rate, ascertainment of digital addiction, and thoroughness of descriptive data reporting (Appendix D in the Supplement). Each dimension has a score of 0 or 1, and a total score of 0 to 2 was considered as having a high risk in quality. Four researchers independently scored on each included study, and then discrepancies were discussed with the review team. The studies with high risk in quality (NOS score
) were excluded.
2.3. Statistical analysis
The pooled prevalence and

confidence interval (95% CI) of digital addiction were estimated. Multiple types of digital addiction were involved in this analysis, including Internet addiction, game addiction, smartphone addiction, social media addiction, and cybersex addiction. The variance of the raw prevalence from each included study was stabilized using the logit transformation before pooling the prevalence estimates. All estimates were presented after back transformation (Lipsey & Wilson, 2000). Heterogeneity of the pooled prevalence among studies was assessed using Cochrane
Q
and
index. For the Cochrane
Q
test,
represented significant heterogeneity. For
index, values of
or less correspond to low degrees of heterogeneity,
to
to moderate degrees, and greater than

to high degrees (Higgins & Thompson, 2002; Higgins, Thompson, Deeks, & Altman, 2003). As expected, high heterogeneity was observed, so a random-effects model (DerSimonian and Laird method) meta-analysis was used to calculate the pooled prevalence and

CIs (Deeks, Higgins, & Altman, 2019). A leave-one-out sensitivity analysis was applied for each meta-analysis. Funnel plots and the Egger's test were performed to assess publication bias when more than 10 studies were available in a single meta-analysis (Egger, Davey Smith, Schneider, & Minder, 1997; Sterne & Egger, 2001).

We performed subgroup meta-analyses for Internet addiction, game addiction, smartphone addiction, and social media addiction. Stratification analysis was layered for WHO region (WHO, 2021b), World Bank region (World Bank, 2021), time period of publication (each five year as a period), gender, age group (<12 years child/12-18 years adolescent/18 years adult), education level (elementary school/secondary school/university), way of investigation (online/off-line), sample size (<1000/1000), the score of each criterion in NOS (0/1), and screening tool. As for study selection, only commonly used screening tools or commonly used cut-off values were synthesized ("commonly used" refers to those screening tools used in at least 5 studies).

Meta-regression analyses were conducted to explore the source of heterogeneity of the pooled prevalence estimates (Jackson, Law, Rucker, & Schwarzer, 2017). The selected characteristics included WHO region, World Bank region, time period of publication, gender, age group, education level, way of investigation, screening tool and score of the overall NOS. Data analysis was done using R (version 4.0.0) with the "dmetar" package.
S.-Q. Meng et al.
Clinical Psychology Review 92 (2022) 102128
3. Results
3.1. Study selection and characteristics

37,965 records were identified through our searching strategy (Fig. 1). After applying the eligibility criteria, 498 eligible articles with a total of 507 independent studies were included in this systematic review. Across 507 studies, 341 studies provided prevalence data on Internet addiction, 78 on game addiction, 82 on smartphone addiction, 31 on social media addiction, 6 on cybersex addiction, 2 on online gambling, and 1 on general digital addiction (Fig. 2-5, eTables 1-6 in the Supplement). The sample sizes of the included studies ranged from 119 to 223,542 with a total number of 2,127,059. The studies covered 64 countries in 6 WHO regions: 7 (1.30%) studies from 4 countries in the African region, 33 (6.12%) studies from 6 countries in the region of the Americas, 52 (9.65%) studies from 11 countries in the Eastern Mediterranean region, 177 (32.83%) studies from 26 countries in the European region, 44 (8.16%) studies from 7 countries in the South-East Asia region, and 224 (41.56%) studies from 10 countries in the Western Pacific region (eTable 7 in the Supplement). Since we analyzed each subtype of digital addiction separately, the 2 studies of online gambling and the 1 study of general digital addiction were not included in the meta-analysis. As a result, 495 eligible articles (504 studies) were included in the quantitative meta-analysis (
All the 504 included studies had a total quality score of at least 3 (eTables 8-13 in the Supplement). 193
studies met the criterion for sample representativeness (i.e., surveying in multiple institutions, or multiple groups of people). 495
fulfilled the sample size criterion
provided satisfactory comparability between respondents and non-respondents, or had a
response rate of over

. 414 (82.14%) had qualified descriptive statistics with proper measures of dispersion. 494 (98.02%) fulfilled the ascertainment criterion by using a validated tool to screen digital addiction (eTable 14 in the Supplement).
3.2. Internet addiction
Pooled prevalence of Internet addiction from 341 studies
was

(95% CI, 12.90-15.65; Fig. 2). Geographically, the prevalence of Internet addiction was the highest in the WHO African region (34.53%; 95% CI, 30.46-38.83), followed by the Eastern Mediterranean region (30.11%; 95% CI, 23.44-37.74). By contrast, the estimates were relatively lower in the region of the Americas (11.06%; 95% CI, 8.0-15.19) and European region (11.06%; 95% CI, 9.31-13.09,
; Fig. 6A). In terms of economic status, World Bank regions at low income level had the highest prevalence estimates (25.15%; 95% CI, 15.60-37.93;
). From 1999 to 2021, the prevalence of Internet addiction significantly increased with the year of publication (slope
per year increase; 95% CI, 1.25-60.34;

, eTable 15 in the Supplement). When stratified by investigation time, pooled prevalence of 11 studies that were related to COVID-19 increased significantly compared with previous studies (32.39% vs 15.20%,
; eTable 16 in the Supplement). The prevalence of Internet addiction among males (17.15%; 95% CI, 14.89-19.68) was higher than females (11.60%; 95% CI, 9.89-13.57;
). Sample sizes of less than 1000 participants had higher prevalence (17.71%; 95% CI, 15.11-20.66) than those of 1000 or more participants (12.23%; 95% CI, 10.87-13.74;
, Fig. 2). Significant difference was observed among various screening instruments (
, Fig. 2). The 20-item Young's Internet Addiction Test (YIAT-20) was the most widely used screening scale for

and
with a more stringent threshold (eTable 17 in the Supplement). Subgroup analysis indicated no statistically significant difference in the prevalence
of Internet addiction when stratified by other characteristics (Fig. 2).

The pooled prevalence of game addiction from 78 studies
was
(95% CI, 4.80-7.57; Fig. 3). Region of the Americas had the highest prevalence of game addiction (9.85%; 95% CI,

; Fig. 6B). The prevalence peaked during 20052009 (11.76%; 95% CI 11.0712.48), declined during 20102014 (5.92%; 95% CI, 3.559.71), then remained stable over time (5.10% during 20152019, 95% CI 3.677.04), and increased after 2020 (8.33%, 95% CI 5.5212.41). Males (10.71%; 95% CI, 8.2213.85) had significantly higher estimates than females (4.19%; 95% CI, 2.965.90;
). Commonly used screening instruments of game addiction could be classified into two categories - scales adapted from the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition (DSM-5)

criteria for Internet Gaming Disorder, and scales derived from the DSM-IV criteria for gambling disorder or substance use disorder. The DSM-IV-adapted scales were the most commonly applied tools in studies before 2015 (8 in 14 studies,
), yet were largely replaced by DSM-5-based scales after 2015 (44 in 64 studies,
, data not shown). Studies using scales based on DSM-5 and DSM-IV criteria did not display significant differences in prevalence (
vs
). The prevalence of game addiction did not differ significantly when stratified by other characteristics (Fig. 3).

3.4. Smartphone addiction
Regarding smartphone addiction, the pooled prevalence from 82 studies
was
(95% CI, 22.73-31.73; Fig. 4). Similar to Internet addiction, the prevalence of smartphone addiction was relatively high in the South-East Asia region (41.63%; 95% CI,

23.02-62.99) and the Eastern Mediterranean region (38.88%; 95% CI, 26.14-53.34), and relatively low in the European region (18.51%; 95% CI, 11.44-28.54; Fig. 6C). World Bank regions at lower-middle income level had the highest prevalence estimates (43.84%; 95% CI, 30.65-57.95;
). The reported prevalence estimates of smartphone addiction were mainly published after 2015 (74 studies,

). Prevalence among adults (26.84%; 95% CI, 20.92-33.73) was higher compared with adolescents (21.62%; 95% CI, 15.88-28.74)
). Among the three screening instruments used in more than 5 studies, significant differences in prevalence estimates were observed (
). Subgroup analysis indicated no statistically significant difference in the prevalence of smartphone addiction by other characteristics (Fig. 4).

(95% CI, 12.42-23.89; Fig. 5). Geographically, similar to smartphone addiction, the prevalence in the South-East Asia region was relatively high (59.36%; 95% CI, 30.37-83.03), and the prevalence in the region of the Americas was relatively low (11.66%; 95% CI, 5.72-22.33;

). Most of the related studies were published after 2015 (28 studies,
). The prevalence based on the 6-item Bergen Facebook Addiction Scale (BFAS-6, 42.46%; 95% CI, 27.18-59.33) was significantly higher (

) than that based on the 6-item Bergen Social Media Addiction Scale (BSMAS-6, 14.85%; 95% CI, 7.78-26.51). No significant difference was observed in the prevalence of social media addiction by other characteristics (Fig. 5).
3.6. Cybersex addiction
The prevalence of cybersex addiction was reported in only 6 studies, so subgroup analysis was not conducted. The estimates ranged from
to
, with a pooled prevalence of
(95% CI, 5.75-11.66). All studies on cybersex addiction were from Europe.
3.7. Publication bias and sensitivity analysis
No publication bias was observed according to visual inspection of funnel plot and Egger's test for Internet addiction
, smartphone addiction
, and social media addiction
, eFigure 1 in the Supplement). As for game addiction, bias assessment showed asymmetry in the funnel plot (Egger's test
, eFigure 1 in the Supplement). This bias was possibly related to the facts that studies with less representative sample (NOS sample representativeness
score
) showed higher prevalence of game addiction than those with more representative sample (NOS sample representativeness score
vs
; Fig. 3). Sensitivity analysis of each type of digital addiction showed that no single study had an excessive influence on the pooled prevalence (eFigures 2-5 in the Supplement).
4. Discussion

To our knowledge, the present study is the first systematic review and meta-analysis to comprehensively estimate the worldwide pooled prevalence of multiple subtypes of digital addiction in general population, based on available data from inception of each database to October 31, 2021. Our findings showed the pooled estimate of prevalence across subtypes of digital devices or related activities with substantial variability. More importantly, we provided meta-analytic evidence that COVID-19 exacerbated the increasing trend of Internet addiction. For Internet, smartphone, and social media addiction, the prevalence varied with different assessments. Higher prevalence of Internet addiction, and smartphone addiction were found in Eastern Mediterranean region, while higher prevalence of game addiction was found in region of the Americas. Participants from countries with low/ lower-middle income levels had higher burden of digital addiction behavior. Males tended to have higher prevalence of Internet addiction and game addiction than females. Other possible confounding factors included sample size, study quality, and ways of investigation on the prevalence. The present study provided basic information for the prevention of digital addiction globally. Early and comprehensive prevention and intervention strategies for digital addiction are urgently needed worldwide, especially under the influence of COVID-19, which has aggregated the prevalence situation of digital addiction. Research priorities lie in development of appropriate screening tools, reveal of neural mechanisms, epidemiological studies in less-developed regions, and investigation of effective
S.-Q. Meng et al.
Clinical Psychology Review 92 (2022) 102128
therapies.
4.1. Geographical distribution of digital addiction

Most subtypes of digital addiction (Internet, game, smartphone, and social media) had relatively high prevalence estimates in the Eastern Mediterranean region, while had relatively low prevalence in the European region and the Americas (except for game addiction). Similarly, previous meta-analyses showed high prevalence rates of Internet addiction in the Middle East region, and low prevalence in Northern and Western Europe, and revealed inverse association between prevalence of Internet addiction and low quality of real life (Cheng & Li, 2014; Modara et al., 2017). Participants with economic or social disadvantages are more likely to use digital media to build connections, self-medicate, reduce stress, and alleviate mood as an escape from the unsatisfied outer environment (Jang & Ji, 2012; Lopez-Fernandez, 2018), which is consistent with our findings that the prevalence of digital addiction was relatively high in the World Bank low or lower-middle income regions. However, regional distribution in game addiction was different from other subtypes. Higher prevalence of game addiction was found in region of the Americas and Western Pacific region, which mainly included the United States, Canada, Brazil, Mexico, China, South Korea, and Singapore in the present study. The estimated prevalence of game addiction in our study was higher than that reported in a meta-analysis with studies from 2009 to 2019 (Stevens et al., 2020), which included more European studies and fewer American and Asian studies. This regional distribution characteristics in our study were in line with some previous meta-analyses (Fam, 2018; Long et al., 2018; Stevens et al., 2020) and had been linked to rapid development of game-related industry, well-acceptance of game culture, and prevailing of e-sports in these American and Asian countries (Chung, Sum, Chan, Lai, & Cheng, 2019; Humphreys, 2019). Besides cultural factors, the regional disparities of prevalence of digital addiction may also be attributed to differences in sample representativeness. For example, the prevalence of Internet addiction in the WHO African region were found to be higher than the Eastern Mediterranean region, while they were only based on small samples of community adults (Tiego et al., 2019) and university students (Asrese & Muche, 2020; Mboya et al., 2020). Similarly, social media addiction exhibited the highest prevalence in the South-East Asia region, yet only a sample of Thai high school students (Khumsri, Yingyeun, Manwong, Hanprathet, & Phanasathit, 2015) and two samples of Bangladeshi university students were included (Jahan et al., 2021; Mamun & Griffiths, 2019). Samples in these studies are not representative of the whole population, and thus the findings of these regions should be taken with caution. This also revealed a gap to be filled that estimates were lack in low and lower-middle income countries in the African region and South-East Asia region. Compared with the high-income countries, these regions are likely to have higher prevalence of digital addiction and fewer support on public mental health (WHO, 2021a), thus highlighting a need to prioritize relevant studies in these regions.
4.2. Prevalence trend of digital addiction over time
In the present study, we included studies before October 31, 2021, and found that global pooled prevalence was
for smartphone addiction,
for Internet addiction, and
for game addiction. In comparison with previous studies, a meta-analysis on Internet addiction including research before 2018 obtained a prevalence of
(Pan et al., 2020), and another with research before 2012 got a prevalence of
(Cheng & Li, 2014), suggesting an increasing trend of Internet addiction over time; prevalence estimates of game addiction vary between
to
(Ferguson et al., 2011; Stevens et al., 2020); meta-analysis of smartphone addiction had only been conducted for children and young people with a median prevalence of
(Sohn et al., 2019). The reason why the present study obtained higher pooled
prevalence of Internet addiction than previous meta-analyses may be that we included latest studies which displayed increasing prevalence, as well as non-English studies, from four major databases.

In the past decades, rapid penetration of Internet and development of technologies worldwide allowed easier access to computers, smartphones, iPads, and various online applications (e.g., video games, Facebook, and Twitter). Our results showed that the prevalence of Internet addiction maintained a long-term growth during the past two decades. Consistently, a meta-analysis of 113 epidemiologic studies covering 693,306 subjects published from 1996 to 2018 also found that prevalence of Internet addiction increased over time (Pan et al., 2020). This rings an alarm for the policymakers to formulate effective strategies to reduce Internet addiction. Smartphone and social media addiction emerged and grew during the past decade. The prevalence of smartphone addiction published during 2020 to 2021 was the highest. The problematic smartphone use, especially among university students needs more attention. However, consistent with findings in other metaanalysis (Feng et al., 2017; Pan et al., 2020), in contrast to the expanding market of online and off-line videogames, we did not find an increasing trend in game addiction during the past decades, which may result from the imbalanced sample sizes and methodological differences between subgroups (Fam, 2018). Specifically, the three included studies (Grusser, Thalemann, Albrecht, & Thalemann, 2005; Grusser, Thalemann, & Griffiths, 2007; Li, Wang, & Wang, 2008) in 2005-2009 subgroup with relatively small sample sizes did not use screening scales adapted from the DSM-IV criteria as most studies during 2010-2014 did, which might lead to an overestimated prevalence for 2005-2009. The prevalence of game addiction from 2010 to 2014 to 2015-2019 was relatively stable, similar with the trend reported in a review based on national representative samples from 2007 to 2016 (Feng et al., 2017). After the issue of DSM-5 in 2013, measures of game addiction were mainly based on criteria of Internet gaming disorder in DSM-5, which is stricter and tends to come to a lower prevalence estimate compared with previous measures according to our results. Therefore, this relatively stable trend was possibly due to the combined effects of the booming game market and the changes in screening and diagnostic methods.

Starting from December 2019, the COVID-19 pandemic has caused serious threat to the whole world. Home quarantine during the pandemic has given people more time and opportunities to access the digital devices for work, study, and entertainment. Furthermore, the pandemic and quarantine induced widespread psychological problems, which increased risks for development of addictive behaviors (Li et al., 2021; Sun et al., 2020; Wang et al., 2021). Studies since 2020 have reported that the prevalence of digital addiction have dramatically grown under the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic (Dong, Yang, Lu, & Hao, 2020; Islam et al., 2020; Li et al., 2021; Lin, 2020; Siste et al., 2020; Sun et al., 2020), consistent with findings of our study. The present meta-analysis included 11 surveys on Internet addiction related to COVID-19, and found that the prevalence rates dramatically increased compared with non-pandemic-related surveys (eTable 16 in the Supplement). These findings emphasized the importance and necessity of prevention and intervention of digital addiction during the pandemic. Although some guidelines have been released to reduce use of digital devices and prevent Internet addiction (Meng et al., 2020; WHO, 2020), population-specific strategies for different subtypes of digital addiction need to be developed during and post the pandemic.
4.3. Differences between screening tools

Shifting definition of subtypes of digital addiction had driven heterogeneity in prevalence estimates. Regarding Internet addiction, the included studies applied over 40 screening scales and showed a surprising amount of variability. The most commonly used tool was YIAT-20, which was adapted from DSM-IV criteria for gambling disorder and alcohol use disorder. Yet, as a screening scale instead of diagnostic criteria, YIAT-20 had been reported to have limited clinical utility for
S.-Q. Meng et al.
Clinical Psychology Review 92 (2022) 102128

evaluating the severity of Internet addiction (Ha, Yu, Park, Ryu, & Kim, 2012). As for game addiction, DSM-5-based screening tools are more strict and suitable to clinical diagnosis compared with other screening tools, and resulted in lower prevalence estimates (Fam, 2018). We also found a similar trend that studies using DSM-5-based screening tools tended to show lower prevalence than those with DSM-IV-based tools, but the differences were not statistically significant. For smartphone addiction, the 15-item Korean Smartphone Addiction Scale (S-Scale-15) was only used in studies in South Korea, the 10-item Questionnaire for Mobile Phone-related Experiences (CERM-10) was only applied in Europe and the Americas, and the Smartphone Addiction Scale-Short Version (SAS-SV) was applied worldwide. For social media addiction, BSMAS-6 and BFAS-6 were used for general and specific social media addiction, respectively, and we found that the prevalence based on the BFAS-6 was significantly higher than that based on the BSMAS-6. Thus, the discrepancies between these scales possibly resulted from regional disparity or their applicable subtypes. In addition, only one study used a scale for general digital addiction (Hawi, Samaha, & Griffiths, 2019). Systematic screening tools for digital addiction and various subtypes are needed in future studies and clinical practice.
4.4. Limitations

As far as we know, this is the first meta-analysis that analyzed and compared the prevalence characteristics of multiple subtypes of digital addiction together, and covered the largest population among studies on similar topics. However, several limitations need to be addressed. Firstly, considerable heterogeneity was identified across most estimates

, creating large uncertainty around the pooled estimates. Through subgroup analysis and meta-regression, this heterogeneity could be partly explained by the variance of study design (e.g., WHO/World Bank region, publication period, gender, and sample representativeness). It needs to be emphasized that, as discussed above, differences in assessment scales for each subtype of digital addiction increased the heterogeneity. Secondly, to ensure the quality of included data, the analysis relied on studies published in peer-reviewed journals and did not include grey literatures. This strategy may avoid increasing heterogeneity but was also likely to result in miss of potentially available data. Thirdly, some included studies adapted online sampling, volunteer participation, or convenient sampling, which increased the risk to get selective samples. To reduce the risk of bias caused by selective sampling, we had already excluded some high-risk studies through NOS quality assessment. Fourthly, because of the absence of data, the results of this study were unable to fully represent the conditions of low-income countries. Finally, compared with clinical interviews, the self-report scales applied in most of the included studies were more likely to get results deviated from the actual conditions.
4.5. Conclusions
In conclusion, by synthesizing the prevalence data, we found that up to one-fourth of the general population could be affected by at least one subtype of digital addiction. Prevalence ranged from
for game addiction to

for smartphone addiction, with big variations between regions, economic levels, time periods of publication, genders, and assessment scales. Given the widespread use of digital media and its potential adverse effects on physical and mental health, this study could help to understand the characteristics of different subtypes of digital addiction, and provide evidence for developing population-specific and cultural-specific preventive management and intervention strategies. An ongoing challenge in the field is that standard criteria for digital addiction have not been established. Greater agreement in terms of the definitions, subtypes, and measures of digital addiction is needed.
